titleStmt.title: A CRAMBO on BALLYSPELLIN, a Place in Ireland, fam'd for its Mineral Waters.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: To the Tune of Sally.
The following Piece will not perhaps be an unacceptable Holiday Amusement to many of our Readers.
I.
ALL you that wou'dRefine your Blood,
As pure as fam'd Luellin,By Waters clear;Come once a Year
To drink at Ballyspellin.II.
If Pox or Itch Your Skins inrich
With Rubies past the telling,'Twill cure your SkinBefore you've been
A Month at Ballyspellin.III.
If Lady's Cheek Be green as Leek
When she comes from her Dweling,The kindling RoseWithin it blows
When she's at Ballyspellin.IV.
The sooty Brown That comes from Town
Grows here as fair as Hellen;Then back she goesTo kill the Beaux,
By Dint of Ballyspellin.V.
All Ladies here Are fresh and fair
As Rose, or bright Dunkellin;And Mars might makeA fair Mistake,
Were he at Ballyspellin.VI.
We Men submit As they think fit,
And here is no rebelling;The Reason's plain,The Lady's reign,
They're Queens at Ballyspellin.VII.
By matchless Charms Unconquer'd Arms,
They have the Power of quellingSuch desperate FoesAs dare oppose
Their Power at Ballyspellin.VIII.
Cold Water turns To Fire, and burns,
I know, because I fell inA Stream which cameFrom one bright Dame,
Who drank at BallyspellinIX.
Fine Beaux advance Equipt for Dance,
And bring their Ann or Nell in,With so much Grace,I'm sure no Place
Can vie with Ballyspellin.X.
No Politicks, No subtle Tricks,
No Man his Country selling,We eat, we drink,We never think
Of these at Ballyspellin.XI.
The troubl'd in Mind, The puff'd with Wind,
Do all come here Pell-mell in,And they are sureTo work their Cure,
By drinking Ballyspellin.XII.
If Dropsy fills You to the Gills,
From Top to Toe tho' swelling,Pour in, pour out,You'll find, no doubt,
A Cure at Ballyspellin.XIII.
Thro' all these Parts Death throws no Darts,
No Sexton's here a Knelling;Come judge and try,You'll never die,
But live at Ballyspellin:XIV.
Except you feel Darts tipt with Steel,
Which here are ev'ry Belle in,When from their EyesSweet Ruin flies,
We die at Ballyspellin.XV.
Good Cheer, sweet Air, Much Joy, no Care,
Your Taste, your Sight, your SmellingcroptYour Ears, your Touch,Transported much
Each Day at Ballyspellin.XVI.
Within this Ground, All Folks sleep sound,
No noisy Dogs a yelling,Except you wake,For Caelia's Sake,
All Night at Ballyspellin.XVII.
Here All you see, Both he and she,
No Lady keeps her Cell in,But all partakeThe Mirth we make
Who drink at Ballyspellin.XVIII.
My Rhimes are gone, I think I've none,
Except I should bring Hell in;But since I'm here,To Heav'n so near,
I can't at Ballyspellin.438-28KL
